item.title: Days Gone Remastered: How to Defeat the Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint Horde
item.description:
The Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint in Days Gone Remastered offers players a valuable opportunity to secure a permanent stat upgrade, loot, and weapon storage. However, accessing the checkpoint isn’t as simple as fueling up the generator and flipping a switch.

A dangerous Horde roams the area, and if players aren't careful, restoring power can turn into a deadly mistake. This guide explains how to properly prepare, eliminate the Horde, restore power safely, and claim the reward inside the Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint in Days Gone Remastered.

How to Defeat the Horde at the Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint in Days Gone Remastered

Prepare for Battle

Before approaching the Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint, players must ensure Deacon is fully prepared. Stocking up on ammunition, crafting numerous throwable items such as Molotov cocktails and grenades, and carrying stamina and health boosters are essential steps. Without these supplies, surviving a whole Horde encounter becomes much more difficult.

Supplies

Description

Recipe

Stamina Cocktail

Restores a small amount of Stamina when consumed.

  • 1 Rag
  • 1 Berry
  • 1 Sterilizer

Bandages

Restores a portion of Health when applied.

  • 1 Rag
  • 1 Sterilizer

Molotov Cocktail

Throwable object that explodes upon contact.

  • 1 Kerosene
  • 1 Rag
  • 1 Beer Bottle

Ammunition and weapons can be purchased from certain camps around the map. Players will receive better-quality weaponry options as they build trust levels with camps.

Players should also leave their motorcycle at a safe distance. Bringing the bike too close risks attracting unwanted attention with engine noise, potentially triggering the Horde before Deacon is ready to engage.

Clearing the Horse Lake Horde

When approaching the checkpoint, it’s crucial to focus on defeating the Horde before attempting to activate the generator. Powering up the NERO systems generates a lot of noise and can attract nearby Freakers to the location. Taking out the Horde first ensures a much safer restoration process.

The Horde is hiding in the abandoned train car over the bridge at the NERO Checkpoint. If players approach it, Freaks will rain down on them in the dozens. To engage the Horde effectively, players should use Attractors to draw them out of the train car.

Once the Freakers are clustered, explosives become devastating tools. The area around the checkpoint includes several fuel boxes and red barrels that can be shot to trigger massive explosions, thinning the Horde’s numbers dramatically.

One of the best environmental opportunities is the gasoline truck located near the checkpoint. Players should lure the Horde close to the truck, then ignite it for an explosive result that can wipe out a significant portion of the enemies in a single blast.

Throughout the battle, mobility is key. Players must constantly reposition, avoiding bottlenecks and dead ends where they could become trapped. Staying aware of the environment, using obstacles for cover, and maintaining an escape route at all times will increase the chances of surviving the encounter. Players can use nearby melee weapons to finish off any stragglers.

How to Restore Power at the Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint in Days Gone Remastered

Once the Horde has been eliminated, players can begin restoring power at the Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint without fear of interruption. Follow these steps to bring the facility back online:

  1. Locate a Gasoline Can : Search the nearby area for a red gasoline can, which is required to fuel the generator.
  2. Move the Car : Push the nearby abandoned car up against the checkpoint building. This creates a makeshift ramp to access the roof.
  3. Disable the Speakers : Climb onto the roof using the car. Locate and destroy the two external speakers. Failing to do so will trigger alarms when the generator starts, possibly drawing in remaining Freakers.
  4. Access the Generator Area : Hop the fence surrounding the generator to reach the machinery.
  5. Fuel and Activate : Pour the gasoline into the generator and activate it to restore power to the checkpoint.

With the power restored, the doors to the NERO facility will unlock. Inside, players will find a valuable NERO Injector . These injectors enable Deacon to permanently increase his health, stamina, or focus. Choosing the right upgrade can make a big difference for upcoming challenges in Days Gone Remastered , so players should consider their current playstyle and needs before applying the boost.

By following these steps carefully, players can safely clear out the Horse Lake NERO Checkpoint, upgrade Deacon, and continue surviving the relentless threats of Oregon’s post-apocalyptic wilderness.

6 Images

item.title: Stardew Valley: How to Catch Glacierfish
item.description:
Stardew Valley offers players a variety of peaceful activities, including fishing. But while most fish can be found fairly easily, some are so rare that special conditions must first be met before they can be caught.

The Glacierfish is one of the rarest legendary fish in Stardew Valley , and you can only catch one of them per save. It can also only be caught in a specific location, making it even harder to come by. For those unsure, this guide will outline how you can find and catch the Glacierfish in Stardew Valley .

Updated April 29, 2025, by Artur Novichenko: Catching a Glacierfish in Stardew Valley is easier said than done because of how rare it is. For those who are finding it difficult to do so, this guide provides a detailed rundown on how to catch Glacierfish in Stardew Valley. On top of that, ways to get more than one Glacierfish have also been outlined, and you can now use Legendary fish to get Roe .

How To Catch Glacierfish In Stardew Valley

Like other legendary fish, the Glacierfish can only be caught once per safe file or once per player in multiplayer in Stardew Valley , but this does not mean that you need to fish in every body of water, hoping to find the right one. Instead, you need to meet these requirements to catch the Glacierfish in Stardew Valley :

  • You must have reached Fishing skill level 6 or higher. Fishing Buffs can be used for this.
  • You should fish during the winter season.
  • Lastly, you must catch the Glacierfish at a specific location in Stardew Valley .

The last condition is the most important, since you will not be able to catch Glacierfish anywhere else. You should head to the southwest of Cindersap Forest . There, you will find a small island. Go down to the southernmost part of the island and cast your fishing rod down.

The Glacierfish does not like to swim close to shore. As such, you should cast the line further into the water to improve your chances.

We also recommend using a Trap Bobber to make it easier to catch this legendary fish. If all the conditions are met, only a few attempts will be needed for you to catch the Glacierfish in Stardew Valley .

How To Get More Glacierfish

Although you can only catch Glacierfish once with a fishing rod, that doesn't mean you can't get this fish in other ways in Stardew Valley . The first way is to use Challenge Bait , which can help you catch up to 3 of the same Legendary fish.

In addition, players can use pans in combination with the Fisher enchantment. The latter grants players a 10% chance to get the fish of the current location as a panning reward. But to do this, you need to use pans in the same place where you fish. Both of these methods will only work if you have not yet caught Glacierfish using the rod.

What To Do With Glacierfish In Stardew Valley

The Glacierfish is more of a challenge than a valuable thing. Despite its rarity, it is not needed to craft special items. Moreover, not a single villager likes this fish as a gift. Therefore, the only thing you can do with it is sell it for Gold, cook simple fish dishes, or place it in a Fish Pond.

With the first option, players can earn up to 3,000 Gold for it. If players would rather not part with this rare specimen, they can also keep it as a souvenir or a prize for completing the fishing challenge. In a pond, your Glacierfish can produce up to 4 Roe.

It is also worth noting that you can get Roe in Stardew Valley by opening Fishing Treasure Chests, provided that you have the power from the Jewels Of The Sea book.

item.title: Brawl Stars: Best Jae-Yong Build
item.description:
Brawl Stars has a stacked roster of 90 brawlers, each with their own abilities and playstyles. But not every brawler makes it to the top. Jae-Yong is a clear exception — this new fighter has an insanely strong super and can even make S-tier brawlers struggle to keep up.

Jae-Yong is a middle-aged office worker who loves karaoke, and his skills reflect his true personality. That said, he does have a few weaknesses that can lower his chances of winning if not handled properly. That’s why choosing the right build for him is crucial to unlocking his full potential. This guide will walk you through the best build for Jae-Yong in Brawl Stars , along with a quick overview of his abilities.

Jae-Yong Skills and Abilities in Brawl Stars, Explained

  • Jae-Yong's Health: 3,400
  • Jae-Yong's Attack: 850

Jae-Yong is a Mythic support brawler in Brawl Stars , and he’s really good at giving buffs and healing teammates. His Super, Mix It Up!, shows how much of a team player he is. It randomly switches between two modes — Work and Party — without you needing to do anything. When Jae-Yong is in Work mode , he makes nearby teammates move 30% faster for a short time. When he’s in Party mode , he heals his closest teammates for 750 health.

Thanks to his Time Trait, his Super charges automatically every six seconds, so you don’t even need to hit anyone to charge it up. His attack also changes depending on which mode he’s in. In the first mode (Work), he fires speakers that do a little bit of damage but boosts speed for teammates, while in the second one (Party), he throws bottles that deal pretty good damage to enemies and heals friends.

Best Jae-Yong Build in Brawl Stars

The best build for Jae-Yong really depends on how you want to play him. Naturally, Jae-Yong is a support brawler, so he’s pretty weak against Assassins, Damage Dealers, Marksmen, and Tank classes because of his low health and attack stats. To help him out, you’ll want to boost both of those areas. The best gadget for Jae-Yong in Brawl Stars is Weekend Warrior —it increases his main attack damage by five seconds, and the cooldown is only 15 seconds, so you can use it pretty often.

When it comes to gears, go for Damage - Super Rare Gear in the first slot (unlocks at Power Level 8) and Shield - Super Rare Gear in the second slot (unlocks at Power Level 10). These will make him hit harder and take less damage. To really turn him into a beast, equip the Extra High Note Star Power —it gives his main attack 20% more damage.

Here’s a quick look at another strong setup for him that you might want to try out:

  • Gadget: Weekend Warrior
  • Gear 1: Damage - Super Rare Gear
  • Star Power: Extra High Note
  • Gear 2: Gadget Cooldown

Along with picking the right build, make sure to max out Jae-Yong’s upgrades, too.

item.title: Final Fantasy: 7 Games With The Best Limit Break Systems, Ranked
item.description:
Up against a hardcore boss and running low on hi-potions? Limit breaks in Final Fantasy are super attacks that usually trigger when a character has taken significant damage, filled a special gauge, or met specific conditions.​ They are as intrinsic to characters as their job, impossible hairstyle, or back story, and on top of that, tend to be among their most stylish moves.

Everyone has their breaking point, whether that's running low on potions during a boss fight or being ambushed for the fifth consecutive time by one of Final Fantasy 's most annoying enemies. But limit breaks help to relieve the tension of a fight, reflect the party's emotional state, or deliver a satisfying, cinematic finishing move.

7 Desperation Attack - Final Fantasy 6

A (Proto) Limit Break System With Some Interesting Ideas

Your comment has not been saved

Final Fantasy 6
11
9.0 /10
Released
October 11, 1994

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Fantasy Violence, Partial Nudity
Powered by

Final Fantasy 6 introduced the concept of limit breaks, albeit in a different state than they would come to be known. Desperation attacks have a small (6.25%) chance to occur when a character's hit points drop below 1/8ths of their maximum, so long as the battle has raged on for more than 26 seconds. This special attack can only be used once per battle, and the player has no control over whether it will trigger in place or a regular attack or not.

Despite this unpredictability, desperation attacks are incredibly powerful as they bypass an enemy's armor and have a chance to kill an enemy instantly. Desperation attacks are significantly less flashy than later iterations, but still potentially lead to some epic "snatching victory from the jaws of defeat" moments.

6 Trance - Final Fantasy 9

A Super Cool Concept With A Highly Flawed Implementation

Your comment has not been saved

Final Fantasy 9
14
9.6 /10
Released
July 7, 2000

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Violence, Mild Language
Powered by

The Limit Break system in Final Fantasy 9 , known as "trance," has plenty going for it, but it comes with a fatal flaw that drops it down in the ranking for most fans. Tranced characters gain a flashy aura around them, granting them heightened stats and special abilities that can devastate enemies.

The mechanic is even integrated into the story. Major bosses turn up the threat level when they discover that their emotions are the key to unlocking this greater power, or when party members are blocked from using it due to emotional blunting. The core problem with trance is that, once its meter is filled, it triggers whether it would be useful or not, leaving players feeling annoyed that it triggered in a random battle and not when it needs to during an important fight.

5 Full ATB Attacks - Final Fantasy 13

Pulling Off An All-Out Attack At An Opportune Moment

Your comment has not been saved

Final Fantasy 13
6 /10
7.3 /10
Released
March 9, 2010

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Powered by

If nothing else, Final Fantasy 13 has style, and this is reflected in its limit break system, where each character can pull off their own unique "Full ATB Skills" (named after Active Time Battle) by spending all of their action points at once. Characters are not required to be at low health or the victim of a flurry of blows, but they might be considered final stand actions in some situations.

Full ATB attacks are unlocked after a certain story step and come with character-specific and highly stylish animations. Their most effective usage is when an enemy is staggered. They are an interesting twist that puts control firmly in the player's hands and makes an all-out attack feel like a risky draw outside the right moment.

4 Quickening - Final Fantasy 12

Chaining Devastating Attacks for Maximum Carnage

Your comment has not been saved

Final Fantasy 12
8.8 /10
Released
October 31, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Alcohol Reference, Fantasy Violence, Mild Language, Partial Nudity, Suggestive Themes
Powered by

Like its approach to the series' classic combat system, Final Fantasy 12 took a unique spin on limit breaks by introducing Quickenings, a system that allows characters to unleash deadly "Concurrences." Unlike traditional limit breaks triggered by damage or desperation, Quickenings require stored "Mist Charges" and involve a mini-game of chaining attacks together in rapid succession.

The strategic layering of Quickenings can lead to absurdly powerful combos culminating in massive finishing moves like Tornado or Inferno that can wipe out even the game's toughest marks. However, missing a chain opportunity can cut a Quickening short, adding a high-risk, high-reward dynamic to an otherwise (arguably) overcalculated battle system.

3 Limit Break - Final Fantasy 7

The Classic System That Redefined ATB Combat

Your comment has not been saved

Final Fantasy 7
14
8.9 /10
Released
January 31, 1997

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Blood, Fantasy Violence, Language, Mild Suggestive Themes
Powered by

This is the system that made Limit Breaks famous and coined the name of the mechanic. In Final Fantasy 7 , a character’s Limit gauge fills as they take damage, eventually allowing them to unleash devastating and iconic special attacks. Each character will have a full roster of Limit Breaks by the end of the game, provided players have unlocked stronger versions by using their Limit Breaks or defeating enemies a certain number of times.

The ultimate, fourth-level limit breaks are unlocked by finding manuals throughout the game. Besides Tifa's punch-up slot machine and Vincent's monster transformations, Final Fantasy 7 's Limit Break system is basic, clean, and simple, which could be a good or bad thing depending on the player. Regardless, it still stands as one of the best. The Remake also did a great job in transferring the ATB system into the real-time hybrid system, and of course, added spectacular animations for each.

2 Limit Break - Final Fantasy 8

Much More Than Just A Stylish Upgrade

Your comment has not been saved

Final Fantasy 8
10
9.8 /10
Released
February 11, 1999

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Mild Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

On the surface, the limit break system in Final Fantasy 8 seems like a simple upgrade from its predecessor, but there is actually a lot more going on under the hood than players might expect. Limit Breaks become available when the player drops below 25% of their maximum health, but the chance of gaining a limit break ability is also determined by a hidden and nuanced "Crisis Level" stat that checks for defeated or condition-afflicted party members.

The Crisis Level also determines which limit break ability the party member will use, if they choose to use it. Almost every party member has a unique limit break mechanic that requires timing (Squall's Renzokuken, Selphie's Slots), button input memorization (Zell's Duel combos), or extra-curricular field studies (Quistis' blue mage monster abilities), which makes battles more frenetic and active. While the junction system leaves each party member something of a blank slate, their limit breaks are an outstanding feature that gives each character bundles of personality.

1 Overdrive - Final Fantasy 10

Personalized, Strategic, and Deeply Satisfying Power Moves

5 Images
5 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Final Fantasy 10
19
9.7 /10
Released
December 17, 2001

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Mild Blood, Mild Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

Final Fantasy 10 's Overdrive system is one of the series' most versatile takes on Limit Breaks. Each character can charge their Overdrive meter in different ways, not just by taking damage, but also by dealing damage, defeating enemies, or helping allies. Either way, the player has control over how to build it up and how to release it.

Executing Overdrives often involves mini-games or timing-based inputs, making them feel more personal and interactive, but without too much waiting through animations. Pulling off a perfect Overdrive at the right moment is incredibly satisfying (and sometimes necessary to survive FF10 's toughest bosses), striking the right balance between depth and simplicity.

item.title: Resident Evil: 8 Monsters Who Can Speak
item.description:
Summary

  • Hearing monsters speak adds eerie depth, implying a struggle to retain humanity during mutation.
  • Mutated enemies from Resident Evil, like Moreau and Lisa, express emotions through speech.
  • Wesker, Nemesis, and others maintain their ability to speak even after drastic mutations occur.

A monster's grotesque appearance can already be more than enough to give players the chills, but there's something so eerie about hearing a mutant or B.O.W from a Resident Evil game actually being able to speak a few words, despite taking on a drastically different form. The implication that these monstrosities are somehow trying to cling onto their humanity, despite their minds and bodies being completely warped, is a scary one to put it mildly, and it's resulted in plenty of freaky moments over the course of this legendary survival horror series.

Monsters who were previously humans, but have succumbed to an infection or disease, can sometimes be able to squeeze a few words out if they manage to retain a part of their former self during the transformation process. On the other hand, there have even been some nightmarish enemies who, despite being manmade, are able to utter some eerie comments while hunting down the protagonist.

8 Salvatore Moreau

Moreau Can Usually Be Found Mumbling About His Obsession With Mother Miranda

Your comment has not been saved

Resident Evil Village
8 /10
20
9.0 /10
Released
May 7, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Powered by

Each of Mother Miranda's four lords who show up in Resident Evil Village is weird in their unique ways. Dimitrescu is a large vampire woman, Heisenberg is a magnetic wizard, Beneviento is a creepy puppet master, and Moreau is a dangerous oddball fishman. The truth is, though he looks like some kind of eldritch monster, Moreau actually has a lot of emotion and is obsessed with trying to win the favor of his master, Mother Miranda.

When Ethan runs into him and steals his flask, Moreau can be spotted staring at a blank TV screen, mumbling about how much he wants to be seen and acknowledged by his mutant mother. His pathetic tirades get even worse when he goes into his full giant fish form, where he cries out to Miranda while trampling all over Ethan as he tries to fend off the dangerous B.O.W.

7 William Birkin

Birkin Holds Onto Just Enough of His Humanity To Express His Fears

5 Images
5 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Resident Evil 2
18
9.1 /10
Released
January 25, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Strong Language, Intense Violence
Powered by

Ironically, William Birkin would become a victim of his own creation, the G-Virus. After being confronted by a group of Umbrella soldiers, one of which being Hunk, Birkin is saved from death by the G-Virus, turning him into a grotesque mutant hell-bent on killing everything in sight, regardless of whether they're friend or foe. As highlighted in his design, Birkin is in the middle of mutating by the time players encounter him, which is why he's also able to speak a few words every so often whenever he tries to resist his primal urges.

Most of the time, Birkin will be attempting to say the name of his daughter, Sherry, as a way to potentially warn her about his infection, which is drawing him to her as it recognizes her as a potential inheritor of the G-embryo. In his fight with Claire and Leon near the beginning of the Resident Evil 2 Remake , Birkin even seems to be showing sympathy for the protagonists, yelling at them to get out of the way while he goes on his mad rampage.

6 Lisa Trevor

Despite Being Grossly Mutated, Lisa Is Still Capable Of Very Basic Speech

6 Images
6 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Resident Evil
Survival Horror
Systems
8.5 /10
Released
April 30, 2002
ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Violence

Powered by

Lisa Trevor is arguably the most tragic character in the series, being someone who was separated from her family at a young age and used as a kind of freak experiment by Wesker and the other scientists. As a result, her physical appearance has entirely changed by the time she appears in the first game, where she can be found mindlessly lurking around the underground area with her shackles scraping across the floor.

However, Lisa is still able to cry out for her mother, though it's clear she's struggling to even speak, considering how distorted her body has become due to all the mutations. It's heartbreaking to hear Lisa scream out for her family, and it ends up making her a very sympathetic enemy when taking her backstory into account.

5 Steve Burnside (Mutant)

Steve Manages To Warn Claire Before Trying To Kill Her

Your comment has not been saved

Resident Evil CODE: Veronica X
Released
March 21, 2001

Platform(s)
PlayStation 2, Sega Dreamcast, GameCube, Xbox 360, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4
Powered by

For most of Code Veronica , Steve acts as a relatively normal, albeit slightly whiny, companion to Claire, who helps her out on quite a few occasions when the two find themselves stranded on Rockfort Island. After the duo find themselves crashing into an Antarctic Umbrella Facility, Steve goes missing, only to end up re-appearing as a mutant who immediately starts swinging for the fences after he spots Claire; seemingly unable to recognize the person he's just spent the last few hours traveling with.

Just as he traps Claire in a corner, Steve fights back against the mutation before he goes for the final blow. Most characters in the series will lose the ability to speak as soon as they mutate, so for Steve to push through and say even a single word, despite the dire circumstances, is impressive and shows just how much he truly cared for Claire Redfield.

4 Alcina Dimitrescu

Dimitrescu Gave Ethan A Rare Glimpse At Her Mutant Bat Form Before He Escaped Her Castle

Your comment has not been saved

Resident Evil Village
8 /10
20
9.0 /10
Released
May 7, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Capcom
Publisher(s)
Capcom
Powered by

It may be hard to believe, but there was a time when Dimitrescu was actually a normal human being, but all of this changed once she met Mother Miranda. After becoming infected with the Cadou parasite, Dimitrescu would grow in size and gain a tremendous boost to her power, while still retaining most of her humanity, which is good considering how much she enjoys belittling anyone unfortunate enough to wander into her castle.

What's most impressive, though, is that Dimitrescu can still speak after mutating into her giant bat form, which she claims nobody outside of Miranda has seen before. It's an extremely unique transformation which Ethan is forced to take on with his limited weapons and resources, all while Dimitreescu hurls insults his way throughout the intense battle.

3 Osmund Saddler (Mutant)

Saddler Preaches His Ideology To Leon One Final Time Before He Bites The Dust

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Resident Evil 4
Survival Horror
Systems
9 /10
55
9.6 /10
Released
March 24, 2023
ESRB
M for Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Capcom
Publisher(s)
Capcom

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Survival is just the beginning.

Six years have passed since the biological disaster in Raccoon City.
Agent Leon S. Kennedy, one of the survivors of the incident, has been sent to rescue the president's kidnapped daughter. He tracks her to a secluded European village, where there is something terribly wrong with the locals.

And the curtain rises on this story of daring rescue and grueling horror where life and death, terror and catharsis intersect.

Featuring modernized gameplay, a reimagined storyline, and vividly detailed graphics, Resident Evil 4 marks the rebirth of an industry juggernaut.

Relive the nightmare that revolutionized survival horror.

Powered by

Saddler is already a creepy enough villain in his normal form, but he becomes pure nightmare fuel when transforming into the multi-limbed spider that faces Leon at the end of Resident Evil 4 . In the remake of the classic game, Saddler decides to get preachy when he faces Leon for the final time, spouting out his belief in the "divine body" in an attempt to win Leon over before he's inevitably taken out.

Remaining fully focused on this boss fight is hard when Saddler is constantly trying to throw Leon, and by extension, the player, off their game in the epic final battle of the game. The fact that Saddler can speak in this form also demonstrates his mastery of the dominant plaga, presenting him as a god-like villain who towers over anyone brave enough to face him.

2 Albert Wesker (Uroboros)

Wesker Can Badmouth Chris Even When He's Being Overtaken By Uroboros

5 Images
5 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Resident Evil 5
10
7.0 /10
Released
March 5, 2009

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Powered by

Chris and Sheva witness many people being absorbed by the deadly Uroboros throughout their journey in Kijuju, but all of them are unable to fight back against the tremendous influence of this unnerving virus before it eventually consumes them. Excella, for example, completely loses control of her body when she is taken over by Uroboros, but Wesker, with his superhuman abilities, is able to fight back against the virus when he fuses with it at the end of the game.

However, it's clear his mind is becoming even more warped than it was before due to the tremendous power surging through his veins, but despite that, he still finds a few opportunities to badmouth Chris and talk about his grand plan for the future of humanity every now and again. Wesker becomes a literal monster by the end of Resident Evil 5 , but Capcom was smart enough to ensure he could still talk his talk, considering this is a huge part of his appeal.

1 Nemesis

With A Single Line, Nemesis Can Send A Chill Down Anyone's Spine

Your comment has not been saved

Resident Evil 3
7 /10
8.4 /10
Released
April 3, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Powered by

Admittedly, the behemoth known as Nemesis, who stalked the Raccoon City streets during the zombie outbreak, is only capable of saying one word, but it's one that's guaranteed to give the player the chills any time he says it. "STARS" is the name of the rescue service Jill is a part of, and also the only word Nemesis will say throughout Resident Evil 3 , since the monster himself was designed solely for the purpose of sniffing out anyone who is affiliated with the group to ensure nobody can spill the beans on Umbrella.

The deep and gravely voice of the Nemesis, paired with his elephant stomps, makes him one of the most intimidating enemies in the entire series. This has become one of the most iconic quotes in all of Resident Evil , and in the remake of the third game, Jill would even use it as a way to mock the ferocious beast when she eventually got the upper hand, which certainly wasn't easy.
